NEWS ANALYSIS
Volatile Public
Gives Labour
'Loveless' Win
Older U.K. Parties Lose Support to Newcomers

By MARK LANDLER LONDON - Britain's voters
handed the Labour Party a land slide election victory this week, but one laden with asterisks.
Prime Minister Keir Starmer Prime Minister Keir Starme
took office on Friday with a
commanding majority in the
British Parliament yet in term British Parliament, yet in terms
of the total number of ballots cast, his party won only a third of
the vote, less than what it got in 2017 when it lost to the Conserva tives. Labour made inroads
across britain, yet its wins wer across Britain, yet its wins were
often eclipsed by the Tory losses,
including that of Liz Truss, the unpopular former prime minister
who was evicted from her seat. who was evicted from her seat.
The thundering mutiny of the voters may have been the single
biggest message of Britain's biggest message of Britain's
election. II has ushered in a new era of Labour government, left
the Conservatives to nurse the worst defeat in their history, and
stands as a warning to ind stands as a warning to incum-
bents everywhere of the hazard bents everywhere of the hazard
of failing to deliver on your of failing to
promises. But Labour's triumph was only
one of several crosscurrents that revealed the extraordinary vola-
tility of the modern British electorate: the rise of Reform U.K., an insurgent anti-immigration
party, which won more than four party, which won more than fo
million votes; the plummeting vote share of the major parties the lowest voter turnout in dec-
ades, and the flare-up of the
Gaza War as a campaign issue Gaza War as a campaign issue
that stung Labour candidates, even Mr. Starmer. While he comfortably held his own seat in London, Mr. Starme
won 17,000 fewer votes than in 2019 , thanks in part to a challenge by an independent who channeled anger on the left over
Labour's stance on Israel and the Labour's stan.
It all added up to a complex election that defies easy categorization: a landslide, but not a
straightforward realignment of the political map; a pivot to the center-left, but one that gave the populist right a valuable foot
hold; a thumping Labour win, hod; a thumping Labour win, suffused Tony Blair's runaway
victory in 1997. "A loveles lan victory in 1997. "A loveless land-
slide," one commentator said on slide," one comm.
Friday morning. "We wanted change," said Anard Menon, a professor of European politics at King's Col
lege London, summing up the lege London, summing up the
complicated state of British politics, "but we aren't inspired
by Labour." by Labour."

from the right-wing wave that is
